repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

comment_data.body:
If `err` is a string, it'd be better to be printed as-is without being wrapped with `"`.

e.g.
```diff
-LSP[lua_ls]: Error ON_ATTACH_ERROR: "path/to/my/config.lua:100: error"
+LSP[lua_ls]: Error ON_ATTACH_ERROR: path/to/my/config.lua:100: error
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1172,6 +1174,16 @@ function lsp.start_client(config)
     return nil, lsp.rpc_response_error(protocol.ErrorCodes.MethodNotFound)
   end
 
+  ---Logs the given error to the LSP log and to the error buffer.
+  ---@param code integer Error code
+  ---@param err any Error arguments
+  local function write_error(code, err)
+    if log.error() then
+      log.error(log_prefix, 'on_error', { code = lsp.client_errors[code], err = err })
+    end
+    err_message(log_prefix, ': Error ', lsp.client_errors[code], ': ', vim.inspect(err))

comment_data.body:
How can we document this behavior? The three (or four) additional codes are custom extensions that is not included in `vim.lsp.rpc`.

FYI, the current documentation about `on_error` `|vim.lsp.start_clinet()|` 

```
                  â€¢ on_error: Callback with parameters (code, ...), invoked
                    when the client operation throws an error. `code` is a
                    number describing the error. Other arguments may be passed
                    depending on the error kind. See
                    `vim.lsp.rpc.client_errors` for possible errors. Use
                    `vim.lsp.rpc.client_errors[code]` to get human-friendly
                    name.
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1180,10 +1192,7 @@ function lsp.start_client(config)
   ---@see vim.lsp.rpc.client_errors for possible errors. Use
   ---`vim.lsp.rpc.client_errors[code]` to get a human-friendly name.
   function dispatch.on_error(code, err)
-    if log.error() then
-      log.error(log_prefix, 'on_error', { code = lsp.client_errors[code], err = err })
-    end
-    err_message(log_prefix, ': Error ', lsp.client_errors[code], ': ', vim.inspect(err))
+    write_error(code, err)
     if config.on_error then
       local status, usererr = pcall(config.on_error, code, err)

@@ -189,7 +189,9 @@ lsp.client_errors = tbl_extend(
   'error',
   lsp_rpc.client_errors,
   vim.tbl_add_reverse_lookup({
-    ON_INIT_CALLBACK_ERROR = table.maxn(lsp_rpc.client_errors) + 1,
+    BEFORE_INIT_CALLBACK_ERROR = table.maxn(lsp_rpc.client_errors) + 1,
+    ON_INIT_CALLBACK_ERROR = table.maxn(lsp_rpc.client_errors) + 2,
+    ON_ATTACH_ERROR = table.maxn(lsp_rpc.client_errors) + 3,

comment_data.body: I'm aware of the documentation of `on_error`, and the way I understand it that function is used when there's an issue once the RPC connection has been established. In this PR I'm dealing with errors that happen before even starting the client, so I'm not sure if that same handler should be used here as well. As for the error codes, there is already an extension to the client codes on master today, but I do agree that they deserve further documentation.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1180,10 +1192,7 @@ function lsp.start_client(config)
   ---@see vim.lsp.rpc.client_errors for possible errors. Use
   ---`vim.lsp.rpc.client_errors[code]` to get a human-friendly name.
   function dispatch.on_error(code, err)
-    if log.error() then
-      log.error(log_prefix, 'on_error', { code = lsp.client_errors[code], err = err })
-    end
-    err_message(log_prefix, ': Error ', lsp.client_errors[code], ': ', vim.inspect(err))
+    write_error(code, err)
     if config.on_error then
       local status, usererr = pcall(config.on_error, code, err)

comment_data.body: Given that the error can be anything, I prefer to keep the generic handling that having small nits for specific cases.

@@ -1391,8 +1400,10 @@ function lsp.start_client(config)
       trace = valid_traces[config.trace] or 'off',
     }
     if config.before_init then
-      -- TODO(ashkan) handle errors here.

comment_data.body: It looks like this function is only ever called with the `err` return value from `pcall`? Is that right? AFAIK `pcall` always returns a string for the error message, so if that's the case then `err` here can be assumed to always be a string.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1172,6 +1174,16 @@ function lsp.start_client(config)
     return nil, lsp.rpc_response_error(protocol.ErrorCodes.MethodNotFound)
   end
 
+  ---Logs the given error to the LSP log and to the error buffer.
+  ---@param code integer Error code
+  ---@param err any Error arguments
+  local function write_error(code, err)
+    if log.error() then
+      log.error(log_prefix, 'on_error', { code = lsp.client_errors[code], err = err })
+    end
+    err_message(log_prefix, ': Error ', lsp.client_errors[code], ': ', vim.inspect(err))

comment_regular_data.body: @wookayin thanks for the feedback! For now I'm just following the existing error handling, which involves writing to the log file and error buffer. I'm open to throwing a `vim.notify` as well.
